
## **The Clock is Ticking: How Do Americans Spend Their Time?** 
#### Authors: Jaeyeon Won (Project Coordinator), Becca Barrick, Jay Maxwell, Alec Meyer, and Tessa Mendoza


## **Introduction**
Every day, individuals in America differently allocate their time between various activities, such as work, leisure, personal care, socializing, and other activities. As understanding this individual time usage is a complicated task, exploring the their time usage as a whole can be helpful in obtaining the general picture on human activity. Practically, it could also be the most valuable resources for promoting social and economic activities performed in the United States, by providing informative analysis. With the purpose of gaining insight into how Americans spend their time, this project investigates the overall trends and patterns of their activity time use in relation to several interesting factors, using various visualizations. Specifically, we explore 7 different types of time use: 'Eating & Drinking', 'Personal Care', 'Religious & Spiritual Activities', 'Socializing, Relaxing & Leisure', 'Sports, Exercise & Recreation', 'Traveling', and 'Work & Work-Related Activities.'

![*People,* 3 January. 2019, *SecretNYC*](https://offloadmedia.feverup.com/secretnyc.co/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/10132249/people-1024x597.jpg)

<hr>

## **Research Questions**
To achieve our goal, we have developed five general areas of exploration with the following five research questions: 

- What are the overall time usage patterns for different demographic?
- How did the trend of time usage change over the last 15 years? 
- How are individual's perceived life satisfaction and time usage related?
- How are individual's general health status and time usage related? 
- What factors are related to individual's work and travel time? 

<hr>

## **Overview of the Dataset**
This section describes how we obtained and cleaned the dataset for this project.

#### **Obtaining the Dataset**
The dataset *time.cvs* comes from the *IPUMS Time Use*, a collaborative research data portal that provides demographic, socioeconomic, household, and daily time use data from survey respondents. Specifically, the dataset was extracted from the *American Time Use Survey (ATUS)* (https://timeuse.ipums.org/), which provides U.S. time diary survey data for period since 2003, using the ATUS extract builder.

The extracted dataset contains 39 variables for approximately 189,866 observations collected from 2004 to 2019. 7 of them are time use variables that were used as response variables, and the other 32 are additional variables that were used to investigate the associations to the time use variables. 

#### **Cleaning the Datset**
The data cleaning process was made relatively simple by the ATUS extract builder, since we were able to export the dataset only with the necessary variables directly as a csv file. The categorical variables in the extracted dataset were encoded as numerical values. To clean this, we renamed the levels with appropriate names based on the codebook provided by the ATUS extract builder. 

Our dataset and the codebook can be found at https://github.com/tessamendoza/ds202_project.git.

## **Exploratory Analysis**

This section explores the basic information about how demographic and living locations are associated to time usage. The demographic factors include age, gender, and race, and the geographical factors involve region and state. The analysis on associations between geography and time use does not include Alaska and Hawaii.

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results=FALSE}
library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggthemes)
library(ggcorrplot)
library(ggpubr)
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results=FALSE}
time = read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tessamendoza/ds202_project/main/time.csv")
statecode = read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tessamendoza/ds202_project/main/state_codes.csv")
states = map_data('state')
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results=FALSE}
# overall data cleaning
statecode = statecode %>%
  mutate(STATE = tolower(STATE))
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results=FALSE}
# clean data
time_jaeyeon = time %>%
  select(REGION, STATEFIP, AGE, SEX, RACE, starts_with('ACT_'))
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results=FALSE}
# Independent variables

# SEX
# Convert type
time_jaeyeon$SEX = as.factor(time_jaeyeon$SEX)
# Rename the levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$SEX) =  c("Male", "Female")
# Check new levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$SEX)

# RACE
# Include only non-mixed races
time_jaeyeon = time_jaeyeon %>%
  filter(RACE %in% c(100, 110, 120, 131, 132))
# Convert type
time_jaeyeon$RACE = as.factor(time_jaeyeon$RACE)
# Rename the levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$RACE) =  c("White only", "Black only", "American Indian, Alaskan Native", "Asian only", "Hawaiian Pacific Islander only")
# Check new levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$RACE)

# REGION
# Convert type
time_jaeyeon$REGION = as.factor(time_jaeyeon$REGION)
# Rename the levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$REGION) =  c("Northeast", "Midwest", "South", "West")
# Check new levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$REGION)

# STATEFIP
# Join
time_jaeyeon = time_jaeyeon %>%
  left_join(statecode, by = "STATEFIP" )
# Convert type
time_jaeyeon$STATE = as.factor(time_jaeyeon$STATE)
# Check new levels
levels(time_jaeyeon$STATE)
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results=FALSE}
# Dependent variables

# Pivot_longer
time_jaeyeon_longer = time_jaeyeon %>%
  pivot_longer(starts_with('ACT_'), names_to = 'TIME_ACTIVITY', values_to = 'TIME_SPENT')
# Convert type
time_jaeyeon_longer$TIME_ACTIVITY = as.factor(time_jaeyeon_longer$TIME_ACTIVITY)
# Rename the levels
levels(time_jaeyeon_longer$TIME_ACTIVITY) =  c("Eating & Drinking", 
                                "Personal Care", 
                                "Religious & Spiritual Activities", 
                                "Socializing, Relaxing & Leisure", 
                                "Sports, Exercise & Recreation", 
                                "Traveling", 
                                "Work & Work-Related Activities")
# Check new levels
levels(time_jaeyeon_longer$TIME_ACTIVITY)
```

**- How Does Time Usage Differ By Age Group?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, fig.align='center'}
# Age Group
time_jaeyeon_longer = time_jaeyeon_longer %>%
  mutate(age_group = case_when(AGE >= 15  & AGE <= 19 ~ '15-19',
                              AGE >= 20  & AGE <= 29 ~ '20-29',
                              AGE >= 30  & AGE <= 39 ~ '30-39',
                              AGE >= 40  & AGE <= 49 ~ '40-49',
                              AGE >= 50  & AGE <= 59 ~ '50-59',
                              AGE >= 60  & AGE <= 69 ~ '60-69',
                              AGE >= 70  & AGE <= 79 ~ '70-79',
                              AGE >= 80  & AGE <= 89 ~ '80-89',
                              AGE >= 20  & AGE <= 29 ~ '20-29'))

# Proportional Barplot
time_jaeyeon_longer %>%
  group_by(age_group, TIME_ACTIVITY) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(TIME_SPENT)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = age_group, weight = avg_time, fill = TIME_ACTIVITY)) + 
  geom_bar(position = 'fill') +
  theme_bw() +
  ggtitle('Proportional Barplot of Time Usage by Age Group') +
  xlab('Activity') +
  ylab('Average Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(fill = 'Activity',
       caption = 'Figure 1: Proportional Bar Graph of Average Time Spent per Day by Age Group (in minutes)') +
  theme(plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        panel.background = element_blank(),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"))
```

Figure 1 illustrates the proportional bar graph of American's time usage pattern by different age groups. We observe here that the amount of time used on personal care stays similar across different age groups. While Americans spend more time on eating and drinking, religious activities, and socializing as they get older, their time use on relatively active activities, such as sports, travels, and work, shows a decreasing trend as getting older.

**- How Does Time Usage Differ By Gender?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, fig.align='center'}
# Side by Side Barplot
time_jaeyeon_longer %>%
  group_by(TIME_ACTIVITY, SEX) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(TIME_SPENT)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(TIME_ACTIVITY, avg_time), weight = avg_time, fill = SEX)) + 
  geom_bar(position = 'dodge') +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_bw() +
  ggtitle('Side-by-Side Barplot of Time Usage by Gender') +
  xlab('Activity') +
  ylab('Average Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(fill = 'Gender',
       caption = 'Figure 2: Side-by-Side Bar Graph of Average Time Spent per Day by Gender (in minutes)') +
  theme(plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        panel.background = element_blank(),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold")) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#00BFC4", "#F8766D"))
```

We see the time usage pattern by gender in Figure 2. Here, it is clear that both males and females spend the most time on personal care and the least time on religious activities. Looking closer, we can also see that males spend relatively more time on socializing, working, traveling, eating and drinking, and exercising than females. On the other hand, females spend more time on their personal care and religious activities than males do.

**- How Does Time Usage Differ By Race?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, fig.align='center'}
# Proportional Barplot
time_jaeyeon_longer %>%
  group_by(TIME_ACTIVITY, RACE) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(TIME_SPENT)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(RACE, avg_time), weight = avg_time, fill = TIME_ACTIVITY)) + 
  geom_bar(position = 'fill') +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_bw() +
  ggtitle('Proportional Barplot of Time Usage by Race') +
  xlab('Race') +
  ylab('Average Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(fill = 'Activity',
       caption = 'Figure 3: Proportional Bar Graph of Average Time Spent per Day by Race (in minutes)') +
  theme(plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        panel.background = element_blank(),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"))
```

Analyzing the the relationship between race and time usage, we found the results above in Figure 3. In detail, we found that different races have a similar trend in general. However, Hawaiian Pacific islanders as well as Asians are determined to spend more time working, on average, than other races. Asians also tend to allocate more time for personal care and eating and drinking. Despite Asians' tendency to work more, they spend the least time socializing, relaxing, and doing leisure activities than other races do.

**- How Does Time Usage Differ By U.S. Region?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, fig.align='center'}
# time_jaeyeon_region for map
time_jaeyeon_region = time_jaeyeon_longer %>%
  group_by(REGION, STATE, TIME_ACTIVITY) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(TIME_SPENT)) %>%
  mutate(STATE = tolower(STATE)) %>%
  left_join(states %>%
              select(-subregion), 
            by = c('STATE' = 'region'))

# time_jaeyeon_region_text for map
time_jaeyeon_region_text = time_jaeyeon_longer %>%
  group_by(REGION, TIME_ACTIVITY) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(TIME_SPENT))

# Map
time_jaeyeon_region %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = long, y = lat, fill = REGION)) +
  geom_polygon(aes(group = group)) +
  coord_map(projection = "albers", lat0 = 39, lat1 = 45) +
  theme_map() +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = -75, y = 42.5, label = "Northeast", size = 4.5, fontface = "bold") +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = -95, y = 42.5, label = "Midwest", size = 5, fontface = "bold") +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = -90, y = 33.7, label = "South", size = 5, fontface = "bold") +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = -113.5, y = 41, label = "West", size = 5, fontface = "bold") +
  annotate("label", x = -53, y = 43, size = 3,
           label = "NORTHEAST \nEating & Drinking: 70.19 \nPersonal Care: 568.13 \nReligious Activities: 10.39 \nRelaxing & Leisure: 300.83 \nSports & Exercise: 19.40 \nTraveling: 74.21 \nWork Activities: 155.67") +
  annotate("label", x = -92, y = 55, size = 3,
           label = "MIDWEST \nEating & Drinking: 66.72 / Personal Care: 569.14 \nReligious Activities: 10.98 / Relaxing & Leisure: 299.32 \nSports & Exercise: 20.13 / Traveling: 69.28 \nWork Activities: 163.97") +
  annotate("label", x = -68, y = 28.8, size = 3,
           label = "SOUTH \nEating & Drinking: 64.15 \nPersonal Care: 583.75 \nReligious Activities: 16.26 \nRelaxing & Leisure: 302.88 \nSports & Exercise: 17.45 \nTraveling: 70.56 \nWork Activities: 155.97") +
  annotate("label", x = -134, y = 42, size = 3,
           label = "WEST \nEating & Drinking: 71.01 \nPersonal Care: 578.03 \nReligious Activities: 10.89 \nRelaxing & Leisure: 279.29 \nSports & Exercise: 22.41 \nTraveling: 72.58 \nWork Activities: 159.20") +
  labs(title = 'Map of the U.S. Regions with Average Time Spent on Each Activity Per Day',
       caption = 'Figure 4: Map of Average Time Spent per Day by Region (in minutes)',
       fill = 'Region') +
  theme(plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"))
```

In terms of the geographical relations to American's time use pattern, we firstly looked at the regions in the United States, which are divided into the four following areas: West, Midwest, Northeast, and South. Based on Figure 4, we observe that people in the West tend to eat and drink the most (71 minutes per day) while the people in the South spend the least time on this activity (64 minutes per day). Similarly, Western people spend around 22 minutes per day on sports, exercise, and recreation, as the leading active region, whereas the Southern people spend the least amount of time (17 minutes per day). On the contrary, these two regions show an opposite pattern in terms of the socializing, relaxing, and leisure activities. For example, Southern residents spend the most time (302 minutes per day) for these activities, whereas the Western people spend the least time (279 minutes per day). Regarding personal care and religious activities, both activities are the most popular in the South while they are both the least popular in the Northeast. The residents in the Midwest are the most hard-working people, while they spend the least time traveling. Unlike from the Midwestern people, the Northeast spends the least time on work-related activities and the most time traveling.

Different time use patterns by state for various types of activities are shown in the 7 maps above. The states with more time spent on each activity are colored in darker colors, and the states with less time spent are colored in brighter colors. 

Comparing the eating and drinking activities and personal care activities, we observe that Vermont, on average, spend the most time eating and drinking and the least time on personal care. On the other hand, Mississippi shows the exact opposite pattern that they spend the most time on personal care and the least time eating and drinking. Similarly, Work-related activities and socializing activities show an opposite trend by state. The states, such as North Dakota, Wyoming, and Colorado, where the work-related activities were the most active time use, spend the least time on socializing activities. Conversely, the states, such West Virginia, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama, where they spend the most time on socializing activities were determined to spend the least time on work-related activities. In terms of the religious and spiritual activities, Mississippi, Alabama, South Carolina, and Utah spend the most time while some of the states in the Northeast region spend the least amount of time. The sports and exercise are the most popular activities in Vermont and Montana. The people in DC and Maryland tend to like to travel the most while the people in Louisiana and Mississippi tend to not.

## **Time Usage Over Time**

This part of the paper investigates how the time usage pattern has changed over the last 15 years from 2004 to 2019. We specifically analyzed the time use trend of the religious and spiritual activities as well as the work and work-related activities.

**- Has time spent engaged in religious and spiritual activities changed over the last 15 years?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
time %>% 
  rename(religion = ACT_RELIG) %>%
  ggplot(time, mapping = aes(x = YEAR, y = religion)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Year') +
  ylab('Total Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Time Usage Trend on Religious & Spiritual Activities (2004 - 2019)',
       caption = 'Figure 12: Time Usage Trend on Religious & Spiritual Activities (2004 - 2019)')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

Figure 12 shows the the amount of time people spend participating in religious activities. Here, we see that it has remained stable since 2004. Every year, the majority is just below 500 minutes per day with a few outliers that spend much larger amounts of time, even going to 1000 minutes per day. Numbers have been relatively lower since 2013. 

**- Are Americans working more or less than they used to?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
ggplot(time, mapping = aes(x = YEAR, y = ACT_WORK)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Year') +
  ylab('Total Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Time Usage Trend on Work & Work-Related Activities (2004 - 2019)',
       caption = 'Figure 13: Time Usage Trend on Work & Work-Related Activities (2004 - 2019)')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

According to Figure 13, the time spent working has also remained pretty stable since 2004. Most people spend at least 1000 minutes a day at work and many people spend up to 1500 minutes a day working. We did some math and realized that 1000 minutes a day equates to over 16.5 hours a day. This data set considers "work" to be activities physically at work, completing any work activities like going to lunch or playing golf with a client, doing anything that makes you money, applying for jobs or interviewing, and many other activities. Obviously not everyone works every single day for that long due to holidays, appointments, and vacations, but 16.5 hours a day is a baseline for lots of people in America. There is a slight dip in minutes worked in 2013, 2016, and 2018. There are many people spending zero minutes working per day which could be because of unemployed adults or children, as this data set includes people as young as 15.

**- How has time spent working changed in various regions of the U.S.?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
time$SEX <- factor(time$SEX, levels = c(1, 2), 
                 labels = c("M", "F"))

time$REGION <- factor(time$REGION, labels = c("Northeast", "Midwest", "South", "West"))

ggplot(time, aes(x = YEAR, y = ACT_WORK, fill = SEX)) + 
  facet_grid(~REGION) + 
  geom_bar(stat = 'identity') +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Year') +
  ylab('Total Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Time Usage Trend on Work & Work-Related Activities (2004 - 2019)',
       caption = 'Figure 14: Time Usage Trend on Work & Work-Related Activities by Region and Gender  (2004 - 2019)',
       fill = 'Gender')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

We also explored the work-related activity time use by region and gender, as shown in Figure 14. Across all regions, minutes per day spent working has been steadily decreasing since 2004. The decline seems to be similar across all regions, with no region seeing a more significant change than any other. The region with the people who work the most is the south. Again, work isn't only the traditional 9-5 in this data set- it includes any work related activities that can make money, applying/interviewing for jobs, or reading things for work at home. People in the south spend more time working than any other region by quite a significant amount. The midwest and the west have people who work similar amounts, and the northeast is where people spend the least amount of time working. We also included gender in my analysis. From what this plot shows, men and women work similar amounts in every region and they are both experiencing the same decline in time spent working since 2004.

## **Life Satisfaction & Time Usage**

This part of analysis shows American's life satisfaction with respect to their time allocation between different types of activities, especially focusing on the work and social activities.

**- How are each type of activities related to life satisfaction?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, fig.align='default', fig.show="hold", out.width="50%"}

  group_by(WBLADDER, REGION, ACT_FOOD, ACT_PCARE, ACT_RELIG, ACT_SOCIAL, ACT_SPORTS, ACT_TRAVEL, ACT_WORK) %>%
  summarise(num = n()) %>%
  filter(WBLADDER != 999) 

time1$WBLADDER <- factor(time1$WBLADDER, labels = c("Worst", "Horrible", "Bad", "Sucks", "Alright", "Fine", "Good", "Great", "Amazing", "Greatest", "Best"))
time1$REGION <- factor(time1$REGION, labels = c("Northeast", "Midwest", "South", "West"))
```

Each of these above graphs shows the average minutes of time at each life quality that people reported for the activity. The most interesting graph of these is the religious activities. There is a large drop off from the first bar where we would assume people are being forced to attend religious activities. Another interesting set would be the personal care graph. Personal care includes sleep which will take up most of the personal care time. Based on this it shows that the more you sleep the lower your life satisfaction.

**- Which region in the U.S. has the highest / lowest life satisfaction?**

Based on Figure 22, most of the regions seem to show a fairly equal life satisfaction. However, Vermont, Idaho, New Mexico, and South Dakota are the most satisfied states with the average satisfaction rating of around 7.4 - 7.5. On the other hand, DC, Utah, Wyoming, Nevada, and New Jersey are the lesat satisfied states with the average life satisfaction rating of around 6.7 - 6.8.

**- Which region spends the most time working?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
time4 <- time %>%
  filter(ACT_WORK != 0)

time4$REGION <- factor(time4$REGION, labels = c("Northeast", "Midwest", "South", "West"))

ggplot(time4, aes(x = REGION, y = ACT_WORK, fill = REGION)) + geom_bar(stat = "summary", fun.y = "mean") +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Region') +
  ylab('Average Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Average Time Spent on Work & Work-Related Activities by Region',
       caption = "Figure 23: Average Time Spent on Work & Work-Related Activities by Region",
       fill = 'Region')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

According to Figure 23, where it shows the time use trend by region, it is easy to see that all of the regions work for a similar amount of time per day. However, the South is determined to be the highest working region with whereas the Northeast and West are the lowest working regions.

**- Which region is the most social? Does this correspond with life satisfaction?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
time5 <- time 

SocByState <- time5 %>%
  group_by(STATEFIP) %>%
  summarize(statecode = mean(ACT_SOCIAL)) %>%
  left_join(statecode, by = c("STATEFIP" = 'STATEFIP'))
stateMap <- states %>%
  left_join(SocByState, by = c('region' = 'STATE'))

ggplot(time1, aes(fill = REGION, x = WBLADDER, y = ACT_SOCIAL)) + geom_bar(stat = "summary", fun.y = "mean", position = "dodge") +   
  labs(x = "Satisfaction", y = "Total Minutes", title = "Social Activites by Region") +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Satisfaction') +
  ylab('Average Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Overall Satisfaction by Region',
       caption = "Figure 24: American's Satisfaction by Region",
       fill = 'Region')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

Figure 24 describes the relationship between the average time spent on social activities per day and the overall life satisfaction by region. Here, we observe that the West is the least social by far. This doesn't necessarily correspond to life satisfaction and the west was equally satisfied compared to the other states.

## **Health & Time Usage**

#### **Physical Activity**

The data provided in this dataset includes individuals ranging from 15-85 years of age. Specifically, this section of analysis explores the 'Sports' time use variable, which highlights the amount of time an individual spends on sports, exercise, and recreation in a day. This will be referenced as physical activity in the future.

**- Which age range spends the most time engaging in physical activity?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
age <- time %>% 
  mutate(agegroup = case_when(AGE >= 15  & AGE <= 19 ~ '15-19',
                              AGE >= 20  & AGE <= 29 ~ '20-29',
                              AGE >= 30  & AGE <= 39 ~ '30-39',
                              AGE >= 40  & AGE <= 49 ~ '40-49',
                              AGE >= 50  & AGE <= 59 ~ '50-59',
                              AGE >= 60  & AGE <= 69 ~ '60-69',
                              AGE >= 70  & AGE <= 79 ~ '70-79',
                              AGE >= 80  & AGE <= 89 ~ '80-89',
                              AGE >= 20  & AGE <= 29 ~ '20-29'))

sportsByAge <- age %>%
  group_by(agegroup) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(ACT_SPORTS))

ggplot(sportsByAge, aes(x = agegroup, y = avg_time, fill = agegroup)) + geom_bar(stat = 'identity')  +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('Age') +
  ylab('Average Time Spent per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Average Active Time by Age',
       caption = "Figure 25: Average Active Time Spent by Age Group",
       fill = 'Age Group')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

Based on Figure 25, the 15-19 year old group spends, on average, the greatest time doing sports, exercise and recreation - over double the amount of time compared to every other age group. Activity level tends to decline as age increases.

The plot above (Figure 26) utilized state data from the R package 'mapdata,' joined with a column of state names and codes (generated by the extract builder and found in the GitHub Repository). As shown in the map, physical activity does vary by state. In general, the Northwest regions are among the most active, while states in the south (especially southeast) are less active. The five most active states are Vermont, Montana, Hawaii, Wyoming, and Colorado  - each averaging between 25 and 30 active minutes per day. The least active states are Delaware, Alabama, Mississippi, South Carolina, and Louisiana - each averaging between 13 and 16 active minutes per day.

#### **BMI**

BMI, or Body Mass Index, is a measure of body fat based on height and weight that is commonly used in the healthcare setting. The BMI data was recorded in the ATUS survey series between 2006-2008 and 2014-2016. The BMI ranges (underweight, normal, overweight, and obese), are determined according to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) standard. It is important to note that BMI is NOT the most accurate predictor of health status, however, it is a useful tool and provides a general marker for individual health, especially on a large-scale level. More information on BMI can be found on the CDC's website (see works cited section for link).

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
bmi <- age %>%
  filter(YEAR == 2006 | YEAR == 2007 | YEAR == 2008 |
           YEAR == 2014 | YEAR == 2015 | YEAR == 2016) %>%
  filter(!is.na(BMI)) %>%
  filter(BMI < 500)

bmi$bmiStatus <- ifelse(bmi$BMI < 18.5, "underweight", 
                        ifelse(bmi$BMI < 25, "normal",
                        ifelse(bmi$BMI < 30, "overweight", 
                               "obese")))

ggplot(bmi, aes(x = BMI, fill = bmiStatus, color = bmiStatus)) + 
  geom_histogram(position = 'identity', bins = 30, alpha = 0.5) + 
  theme_bw() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#28C40C", "#DE2905", "#E8A201", "#8E9CA1")) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#28C40C", "#DE2905", "#E8A201", "#8E9CA1")) +
  xlab('BMI') +
  ylab('Number of Respondents') +
  labs(title = 'Distribution of BMI',
       caption = "Figure 28: Distribution of BMI Status")  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

Figure 28 shows the distribution of BMI's among individuals. BMI status was calculated using the CDC standard and was manually added to the dataset. The most frequent BMI values occur at the higher end of the normal range and at the lower end of the overweight category.

#### **General Health**

One of the variables within the dataset contains self-reported general health status from the survey respondents. The participants were asked to rate their general health as "Excellent," "Very good," "Good," "Fair," or "Poor." Some participants did refuse to answer and others responded "Don't know."

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, results=FALSE, fig.align='center'}
health <- bmi %>%
  filter(!is.na(GENHEALTH)) %>%
  filter(GENHEALTH != 99)
health$GENHEALTH <- factor(health$GENHEALTH, levels = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 96, 97), 
                     labels = c("Excellent", "Very good", "Good", "Fair", "Poor", "Refused", "Don't know"))

ggplot(health, aes(x = GENHEALTH, fill = GENHEALTH)) + 
  geom_bar() +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('General Health') +
  ylab('Number of Respondents') +
  labs(title = 'Distribution of Self-Reported General Health Status',
       caption = "Figure 30: Distribution of Self-Reported General Health Status",
       fill = 'Health Status')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

The general distribution is as shown above in Figure 30: A majority of respondents consider themselves in 'very good' or 'good' health. Interestingly, this slightly contradicts the BMI, objective measurement of health, where a larger majority of individuals are categorized as 'overweight.'

**- How does an individual's health (BMI and general health) relate to the amount of time they spend being physically active?**

```{r, echo=FALSE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE, fig.align='default', fig.show="hold", out.width="50%"}
bmiStatus <- bmi %>%
  mutate(bmiStatus = fct_relevel(bmiStatus, 
                            "underweight", "normal", "overweight", "obese")) %>%
  group_by(bmiStatus) %>%
  summarise(avg_active = mean(ACT_SPORTS))

ggplot(bmiStatus, aes(x = bmiStatus, y = avg_active, fill = bmiStatus)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = 'identity') +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('BMI Status') +
  ylab('Average Active Time per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Activity Levels by BMI Status',
       caption = "Figure 31: Activity Levels by BMI Status",
       fill = 'BMI Status')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

healthTable <- health %>%
  group_by(GENHEALTH) %>%
  summarise(avg_time = mean(ACT_SPORTS))

ggplot(healthTable, aes(x = GENHEALTH, y = avg_time, fill = GENHEALTH)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = 'identity') +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab('General Health') +
  ylab('Average Active Time per Day (in minutes)') +
  labs(title = 'Average Active Time by General Health Status',
       caption = "Figure 32: Average Active Time by General Health Status",
       fill = 'Health Status')  +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```

Figure 31 and Figure 32 show the average active time per day by BMI status and by General health status, respectively. Here, there is a general positive correlation between an individual's amount of activity time and their perceived health level. That is, those who consider themselves in good health tend to be more active.

## **Conclusion**

The IPUMS Time-Use data set covers a wide range of social topics and demographic with the ability to create and download a data-set customized to your own needs. 

<h4>Time Usage Over Time</h4>
Time spent doing religious activities has decreased and time spent working has also decreased an equal amount across all regions in the U.S. 
<h4>Life Satisfaction & Time Usage</h4>
The more a person can diversify their daily activities the greater their perceived life satisfaction will be 
<h4>Health & Time Usage</h4>
increased physical activity does not necessarily correlate to healthier BMI - other factors (nutrition, etc) must be involved
<h4>Work-Life Balance</h4>
Household with and without children, on the average, spend the same amount of time on the activities we examined.
Work and social time have a negative correlation, work and the other activities have little correlation.
